I ate the last female on earth with obvious relish saving every drop of blood untill I had finished the rest. I kept the blood in small vials, fifty two of them, one for every month. And every day I would

run with her to the old path where we walked through the forest greener than the pot we smoked and more quiet than the acid we dropped together or the shrooms we ate. item.title: Criticism Needed
item.dc:creator: @philodespotos philodespotos
item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

It was good. Pat yourself on the back, and indulge in congratulatory orange sounds if that’s your thing. What follows is advice from someone who writes obsessively every bloody day.

The first thing you need to do is cement your editing process. To do so is tedious, typically boring, and doesn’t immediately bear any fruit. But it makes the thousands of times you will repeat it much less cumbersome. I haven’t the slightest what a professional editor does, and don’t much care. My process is: a slow reading for misspellings, grammar, punctuation; a second reading and some chickenscratch to eliminate the most egregious of my 900 word sentences that amount to “the grass is green;” throw everything away and rewrite the entirety in very broad strokes – what do I actually consider important enough not to discard? – 50 pages can typically best be written in 5; with that in mind, go back and trim the fat from the original; now that I’ve got a product that doesn’t make me want to throw in the towel, note what words/tenses/phrases/constructions I’m overusing, and, rather than search for synonyms, get some new fuckin imagery. If I’m repeating the same words in a thousand spots, I need better ideas. This is just generic editing, without any significant changes to content.

I have made only a couple comments on content in my marginscrawling. Mostly, I’ve confined myself to the first two steps. The compliments are genuine; the insults largely suppressed. No need to seem like an ass right out of the box. I’ve also gone easy on punctuation, because it’s so tightly tied to style – as anyone who reads my posts can see, I overpunctuate, but productively. Others underpunctuate, but smoothly. Some follow the prescribed usage. They should be shot.

After many years of effort, it’s been decided that there’s no reasonable way of expressing editing changes without being able to scribble idly, so I’ve done it in the same manner that my friends and I use for each other: print, belittle, spill coffee, dry, scan. My handwriting is a toss up, depending on how early I started drinking. If you can’t read something, you’ll have to ask, or guess.

Anyhow – I do this quite literally every single day, whether with my works or a friend’s. Perfectly happy to look at yours, too, if you’d like. Just email it if you want it read in something approaching a timely fashion. me at gmail.

http://benthos.eggsampler.com/pages.tgz – ca. 11mb, scanned printouts with the notes.

[br][size=1]Posted at: December 20, 2006, 03:42:10 PM[/size][hr]Ok, heres some idea’s and points i thought i’d give.

Point one :
Too many connectives causing uneeded breaks. At a part of suspense it really should flow, breaking it up lowers suspence a bit, however adding certain pauses can increase it. For example :

One with too connectives :

He came in the house and then he took out a knife and i knew he was going to kill me because i had something he wanted.

One which would more flow :

He came into the house, took out a knife. He was going to kill me. I had something he wanted.

I had a look at your third paragraph and this is where it becamse evident to me. It would go really smooth and i’d be like w00t im getting into this lets read on. Then it breaks, and it was annoying since i just wanted to read on instead of being…stopped?

The name Christopher comes from the name Christ somehow, but nobody looked less like Jesus than Chris. First impressions must imprint visually on your brain, because every time I think of Chris I see him standing in the rain on the pavement of our schools parking lot, his black Batman rain jacket hung over him like a cloak, his head down. I see this dark aura around him, surrounding him and deflecting light, keeping him warm and safe. I walked over to him and said hi. 

The name Christopher comes from the name Christ somehow. Nobody looked less like Jesus than Chris. First impressions must imprint visually on your brain, every time I think of Chris I see him standing in the rain on the pavement of our schools parking lot, his black Batman rain jacket hung over him like a cloak, his head down., this dark aura surrounding him, deflecting light, keeping him warm and safe. I walked over to him and said hi.

This is just of course my kinda opinion, some might prefer alot of connectives and find them uh…scarier?

Point 2 :
A change in certain words to add more expression and emotion. For example :

I walked over to him and said hi.

Could be replaced with something like :

I edged over to him

Point 3 :
Repitition, like you so rightly said. The reader needs to fill in the blanks.

I walked over to him and said hi.
Hi was the word that exited my mouth

You could combine the two sentences or just remove a section of once completly to avoid repitition like :

I walked over to him, the only word that managed to escape my mouth was Hi.
I walked over to him. Hi was the word that exited my mouth.

This would be critism that i could only find on the first page. After the story gets going its really, really good. Good job
